questions.text: A 60-year-old woman with a history of cancer presents to the clinic for follow-up. She has been receiving treatment that involves the use of antibodies to target her tumor cells. The physician explains how her immune system can enhance the destruction of these cells. Which of the following cells are not involved in the mechanism described by the physician?
Which of the following represents the correct sequence of events in B cell-T cell interaction leading to antibody production?

options.label: A
options.text: B cells undergo class switching after CD40-CD40L interaction without requiring cytokine signals

options.label: B
options.text: T cells present antigens to B cells via MHC-II molecules

options.label: C
options.text: B cells process antigen, present via MHC-II to T cells, receive CD40L and cytokine signals

options.label: D
options.text: CD28-B7 interaction between B and T cells is sufficient for plasma cell differentiation

questions.correct_answer: C. B cells process antigen, present via MHC-II to T cells, receive CD40L and cytokine signals
questions.explanation:
Stage

Process

Key Components

Initial B Cell Activation

1. Antigen Recognition:

• B cell captures antigen via surface IgM/IgD

• Antigen internalization

 

2. Antigen Processing:

• Processed into peptides

• Loaded onto MHC-II molecules

• B cell receptor (BCR) (IgM and IgD)

• Surface immunoglobulins

• MHC-II molecules

B Cell-T Cell Interaction

1. Signal Generation:

• Signal 1: Antigen presentation to TH cells

• Signal 2: CD40-CD40L interaction

• Signal 3: Cytokine stimulation

 

2. T Cell Help:

• TH1: IFN-γ (IgG production)

• TH2: IL-4 (IgE production)

• TCR-MHC-II complex

• CD40-CD40L

• Cytokine receptors

• Co-stimulatory molecules

B Cell Response

1. Germinal Center Formation:

• B cell proliferation

• Somatic hypermutation

• Class switching

 

2. Differentiation:

• Into plasma cells

• Into memory B cells

• Antibody production

• Affinity maturation

• Immunological memory

Outcomes

1. Immediate Response:

• Antibody secretion

• Different Ig classes based on cytokines

 

2. Long-term Response:

• Memory formation

• Enhanced secondary response

• IgG, IgA, IgE production

• High-affinity antibodies

• Long-lived plasma cells

• Memory B cells

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with a sore throat, fever, and swollen lymph nodes. A throat swab confirms a bacterial infection. As part of the immune response, cells in the lymph nodes begin processing and presenting bacterial antigens to activate CD4+ T helper cells. Which of the following cells is primarily responsible for presenting antigens to CD4+ T helper cells?

A 24-year-old male presents with muscle weakness, difficulty swallowing, blurred vision, and drooping eyelids. Blood tests reveal antibodies against acetylcholine receptors, suggesting myasthenia gravis. The physician explains that the patient's immune system may be reacting to "self" proteins. Which of the following statements best explains the immunological basis for this autoimmune reaction?

options.label: A
options.text: The antigen is presented by MHC Class I molecules to CD8+ T-cells, leading to cytotoxic T-cell-mediated destruction.

options.label: B
options.text: The antigen is presented by MHC Class II molecules to CD4+ T-cells, stimulating an immune response involving helper T-cells and autoantibody production.

options.label: C
options.text: MHC Class I molecules are found only on professional antigen-presenting cells, which present the antigen to helper T-cells.

options.label: D
options.text: MHC Class II molecules are present on all nucleated cells and help in presenting intracellular antigens.

questions.correct_answer: B. The antigen is presented by MHC Class II molecules to CD4+ T-cells, stimulating an immune response involving helper T-cells and autoantibody production.
questions.explanation:
Feature

MHC Class I

MHC Class II

Expression

Found on almost all nucleated cells

Found mainly on antigen-presenting cells (APCs) such as macrophages, dendritic cells, and B-cells

Antigen Source

Presents intracellular antigens (e.g., viral or tumor proteins)

Presents extracellular antigens (e.g., bacterial peptides)

Interacts With

CD8+ T-cells (cytotoxic T-cells)

CD4+ T-cells (helper T-cells)

Main HLA Genes

HLA-A, HLA-B, HLA-C

HLA-DP, HLA-DQ, HLA-DR

Structure

Consists of one α (heavy) chain and β2-microglobulin;

peptide-binding groove formed by α1 and α2

Consists of α and β chains; peptide-binding groove formed by α1 and β1 domains

Function

Identifies and helps eliminate infected or malignant cells by presenting endogenous antigens to CD8+ T-cells

Activates immune response by presenting exogenous antigens to CD4+ T-cells

Peptide Length

Presents shorter peptides (8-10 amino acids)

Presents longer peptides (10-30 amino acids)

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with end-stage renal disease is scheduled for a kidney transplant. The best match for a donor kidney is from his identical twin brother. Which type of graft will this procedure involve?

A 42-year-old woman is being considered for a liver transplant. Her doctors have found a donor with an identical ABO blood group but only partial HLA matching. Which additional test should be performed to assess compatibility further and reduce graft rejection risk?

A 55-year-old woman is undergoing a kidney transplant. During the pre-transplant evaluation, it is discovered that she has pre-existing antibodies against the donor’s HLA antigens due to a previous organ transplant. Which of the following is most likely to occur immediately after transplantation?
questions.explanation:
Type of rejection

Mechanism

Time after transplant

Hyperacute rejection

Mediated by preformed antibodies specific for antigens on graft endothelial cells, these may be natural IgM antibodies specific for blood group antigens, or may be antibodies specific for allogeneic MHC molecules that were induced by prior exposure of the organ recipient to allogeneic cells through blood transfusions, pregnancy, or transplantation of another organ

Minutes to hours

Acute cellular rejection

CD8+ cells may directly destroy graft cells, or CD4+ cells secrete cytokines and induce inflammation, which damages the graft

Anytime (most commonly first 6 months)

Acute antibody-mediated (vascular, or humoral) rejection

Antibodies bind to vascular endothelium and activate complement via the classical pathway.

The resultant inflammation and endothelial damage cause graft failure.

  

Chronic rejection

Chronic rejection is an indolent form of graft damage that occurs over months or years, leading to progressive loss of graft function.

Chronic rejection manifests as interstitial fibrosis and gradual narrowing of graft blood vessels (graft arteriosclerosis).

Usually after 1st year

questions.text: Which factor is NOT typically associated with chronic transplant rejection?

options.label: A
options.text: A) Persistent low-grade immune response despite immunosuppressive therapy.

options.label: B
options.text: Inflammation during the first year post-transplant.

options.label: C
options.text: Antibody-mediated damage leading to tissue injury.

options.label: D
options.text: Non-immune factors like infections and ischemia.

questions.correct_answer: B. Inflammation during the first year post-transplant.
questions.explanation:
Characteristic

Description

Gradual Decline in Graft Function

Slow deterioration of transplanted organ function over time.

Fibrosis and Scarring

Chronic inflammation leads to fibrous tissue deposition, causing scarring and loss of normal organ structure.

Vascular Changes

Thickening and narrowing of blood vessels in the graft, reducing blood flow and causing tissue damage.

Challenge

Description

Complex and Multifactorial

Involves multiple factors, complicating cause identification and therapy development.

Limited Treatment Options

Existing therapies focus on acute rejection prevention; less effective for chronic rejection.

Impact on Long-Term Graft Survival

Major cause of long-term graft failure.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about acute graft-versus-host disease (aGVHD) is true?

options.label: A
options.text: aGVHD typically manifests within the first 30 days post-transplant.

options.label: B
options.text: The primary target organs affected are the skin, liver, and lungs.

options.label: C
options.text: Corticosteroids are the first-line treatment for managing aGVHD.

options.label: D
options.text: aGVHD is solely caused by mismatches in blood type between donor and recipient.

questions.correct_answer: C. Corticosteroids are the first-line treatment for managing aGVHD.
questions.explanation:
Organ

Symptoms

Skin

Maculopapular rash

Liver

Elevated bilirubin levels and liver enzymes

Gastrointestinal Tract

Abdominal pain, diarrhea, nausea, vomiting

Grade

Description

I

Mild involvement

II

Moderate involvement

III

Severe involvement, poor prognosis

IV

Very severe involvement, high mortality risk

questions.text: Which of the following statements about post-transplant complications is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Allograft rejection primarily involves the activation of B lymphocytes leading to antibody production.

options.label: B
options.text: Hyperacute rejection occurs immediately due to pre-existing antibodies in the recipient.

options.label: C
options.text: Graft-versus-host reaction is less likely to occur in immunocompromised recipients.

options.label: D
options.text: Hemolytic disease of the newborn is caused by maternal incompatibility with paternal blood group antigens.

questions.correct_answer: B. Hyperacute rejection occurs immediately due to pre-existing antibodies in the recipient.
questions.explanation:
Type

Description

First-Set Rejection

Initial rejection episode after transplantation.

Second-Set Rejection

More rapid and aggressive response upon re-transplantation from the same donor due to immunological memory.

Hyperacute Rejection

Immediate graft failure due to pre-existing antibodies in the recipient targeting the graft.

questions.text: In which clinical test is the "Ring test" precipitation reaction applied, and what is its primary use?

options.label: A
options.text: Ascoli’s thermo precipitin test for detecting anthrax antigens

options.label: D
options.text: Kahn test for detecting lupus antibodies

questions.correct_answer: A. Ascoli’s thermo precipitin test for detecting anthrax antigens

questions.text: The image below shows a precipitation test in a gel medium in which a circular precipitation pattern is formed due to an antigen-antibody reaction. What type of precipitation test in the gel does this image depict?
questions.explanation:
Type of Diffusion

Double Diffusion

Single Diffusion

One Dimension

Oakley-Fulthorpe Procedure

Oudin Procedure

Two Dimension

Ouchterlony Procedure

Radial Immunodiffusion

questions.text: Which of the following statements best describes the indirect immunofluorescence test?

options.label: A
options.text: A) It requires specific fluorescent conjugates for each antigen being tested.

options.label: B
options.text: It uses an antiglobulin fluorescent conjugate to detect any human antibody, allowing for broader application.

options.label: C
options.text: It directly labels antigens with a fluorescent dye for visualisation.

options.label: D
options.text: It is primarily used to detect antigens in brain smears, such as in rabies diagnosis.

questions.correct_answer: B. It uses an antiglobulin fluorescent conjugate to detect any human antibody, allowing for broader application.
questions.explanation:
Type

Description

Example

Limitation

Direct Immunofluorescence

Detects antigen directly using a fluorescent-labelled antibody.

(Option C ruled out)

Rabies diagnosis via brain smears

(Option D ruled out)

Requires separate fluorescent conjugates for each antigen.

(Option A ruled out)

Indirect Immunofluorescence

It uses antiglobulin fluorescent conjugate to detect human antibodies, enhancing versatility.

Fluorescent treponemal antibody test for syphilis

Allows the use of a single anti-human conjugate.

Advantages

Disadvantages

High sensitivity for detecting small amounts of antigen/antibody.

Non-specific fluorescence due to autofluorescence or non-specific binding.

High specificity with target-specific antibodies.

Photobleaching (loss of fluorescence over time with light exposure).

Versatile: applicable to various samples (tissues, cells, microorganisms).

High cost of equipment and reagents.

Allows direct visualisation, aiding interpretation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a rash and difficulty breathing after being administered penicillin. Which of the following types of hypersensitivity reactions is most likely responsible for her symptoms according to the Gell and Coombs classification?
questions.explanation:
Type

Description

Examples

Type I (Immediate)

(Option A)

IgE-mediated reactions, leading to mast cell degranulation and histamine release.

Examples include allergic rhinitis and anaphylaxis.

Type II (Cytotoxic)

(Option B)

Mediated by IgG or IgM antibodies directed against antigens on cell surfaces or matrix, causing cell lysis.

Conditions include autoimmune hemolytic anemia and rheumatic fever.

Type III (Immune Complex)

(Option C)

Caused by the formation of antigen-antibody complexes that deposit in tissues, leading to inflammation.

Examples include systemic lupus erythematosus and post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.

Type IV (Delayed)

(Option D)

Mediated by T cells, occurring hours to days after exposure to an antigen.

Seen in contact dermatitis and tuberculin reactions.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with fatigue, jaundice, and shortness of breath. Laboratory tests reveal a hemoglobin level of 7.2 g/dL, elevated bilirubin, and a positive direct Coombs test. Peripheral blood smear shows spherocytes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis and its corresponding type of hypersensitivity?

A 30-year-old woman presents with joint pain, fever, and a malar rash. Laboratory tests show proteinuria, low complement levels, and the presence of anti-nuclear antibodies (ANA) and anti-dsDNA antibodies. Which of the following mechanisms best explains the pathology of her disease?

options.label: A
options.text: Direct binding of IgE to mast cells, leading to histamine release

options.label: B
options.text: Antibody-mediated cytotoxicity targeting red blood cell antigens

options.label: C
options.text: Deposition of immune complexes in tissues

options.label: D
options.text: T-cell-mediated cytotoxicity targeting self-antigens on tissue cells

questions.correct_answer: C. Deposition of immune complexes in tissues
